findings.title: Minting of unlimited number of sundae tokens
findings.description: The contract owner can mint tokens at will, arbitrarily freeze accounts, and start or stop the crowdsale at any time.

findings.title: Crowdsale process is not transparent
findings.description: The Ovcode whitepaper does not describe the fine details of the OVC crowdsale, including token generation, distribution, and operation duration. The contract owner has excessive control over minting tokens, freezing accounts, and starting/stopping the crowdsale.

findings.title: Contract owner can mint tokens at will
findings.description: The contract owner has the ability to mint tokens arbitrarily, creating an environment where token purchasers have to place a large amount of trust in Ovcode.

findings.title: Contract owner can arbitrarily freeze accounts
findings.description: The contract owner has the ability to arbitrarily freeze accounts, which creates an environment where token purchasers have to place a large amount of trust in Ovcode.

findings.title: Contract owner can start or stop the crowdsale at any time
findings.description: The contract owner has the ability to start or stop the crowdsale at will, which creates an environment where token purchasers have to place a large amount of trust in Ovcode.

findings.title: Unsold tokens after the end of the crowdsale can be claimed by contract owner
findings.description: The contract owner has the ability to claim unsold tokens at any point after turning off purchases, which could dramatically alter the worth of tokens for individuals receiving initial tokens.

findings.title: Outdated version of Solidity used (0.4.21 instead of 0.4.22)
findings.description: The contracts are using an outdated version of Solidity (0.4.21) instead of the current version (0.4.22), which should be updated before deployment.
